segments.text: Dr. and General Butler, today is July 24, 1980.
This is Terry Anderson.
We were talking last time about the committee.
And it was Ted Noyes.
Yes.
Archie Flowers in the Department of Veterinary Public Health was chairman of the committee.
Ted Noyes, N-O-Y-E-S.
and I were the ones that studied the compulsory ROTC and the COED matter as a committee appointed by then President Rutter.
OK, we're going to talk about your relations with General Rutter later.
Let's get back to where we left off.
Last time, we were talking about the Highway Information Service in the 1930s.
And you said that the corpsman, well, could you explain how that worked?
Well, about 1936 or 1937, the highway information stations were established at the main highway entrances to Texas.
The Civil Engineering Department of Texas A&M had a close connection with the Texas Highway Department.
and I don't know exactly how it came about, but the highway information stations first were opened just in the summertime when the peak tourist load was experienced.
They were manned just in the summer and they were manned by Texas A&M University cadets in uniform.
That went along for several years.
I was assigned one year, let's see, between my sophomore and junior year, so it would have been
1937 to the highway information station at Marshall, Texas on highway 80 coming in from the east Louisiana side.
So I was proud at that time the uniforms were different for the first two-year cadets and for those that were juniors and seniors and really
The ones selected were juniors and seniors.
They were able to wear suede uniforms, whereas the first two-year cadets wore just issue wool uniforms.
So the uniforms worn by the juniors and seniors were a good deal dressier than the issue clothing, wool clothing, that the first two-year cadets wore.

So after you'd completed your sophomore year, you were eligible to buy the suede clothing, so I was pleased to be able to wear that, dressier shirts, herringbone twill for the khaki, and for the wool summer, I mean winter uniform, of course, suede.
I would think that the wool would be awesome.
Well, it wasn't important.
In the summer, you see, we wore the HBT's, the Herringbone Twill, when we manned that station.
The Corps is a whole lot better dressed now.
They do get issue uniforms and they're all the same.
You see, in our days, there was a good deal of distinction
freshman wore a white stripe around their left sleeve down near the cuff, a fish stripe, you know.
So you didn't have any trouble identifying a freshman.
And then the sophomores had the same sort of issue, clothing without the stripe, and the juniors then wore the dressier

clothing but they had to purchase it see that wasn't issued by the government in those days and of course they were identified by non-commissioned officer stripes and the seniors see all had buttons that indicated rank from first lieutenant up through cadet colonel so there's a lot more distinction and of course the seniors also we were all wearing the campaign hats
later came back into style for grill sergeants and all, but we all had them then.
Why did this change and when did it?
Well, the pressure of manufacturing a lot more clothing for the Army when they made the real sharp expansion in the late 30s and early 40s, that campaign had
was an expensive piece of clothing that wasn't really very suitable for combat duty or hard duty in the field, so it fell by the wayside.
It really came on early for horse-drawn artillery and for cavalry troops, you see, and of course they eliminated the horses.
In about 1941,
So there wasn't really any very good excuse.
Of course, the boots that are still worn by our senior cadets, you see, were once part of the official military uniform, too, with the horses.
They fell out of the official uniform status in the early 40s, but thank goodness they've been retained by Texas A&M senior cadets.
That's always been a senior privilege for these boots.
What about the strike for that freshman?
I don't know when that disappeared.
I was surprised when I came back and really never have really learned how to distinguish between first and second year cadets.
Now, because their uniforms look just alike, I'm sure that it was a part of the elimination of the hazing and upgrading the status of the freshman student.

Because during the middle 40s, late 30s, Texas A&M was not all that popular, and particularly when the public sort of, after World War II, the stature of the serviceman decreased and ROTC wasn't as popular.
Texas A&M was doing whatever it could to increase its attractiveness.
Very ironical, I told somebody that for the first 30 years of my association with Texas A&M, I was continually trying to recruit students to come to A&M.
Then about four years ago, I got put on a committee to see how we could turn it off.
Texas A&M got popular all of a sudden.
Are you trying to do that right now?
Decrease the growth?
Well, I'd have to say yes to some degree.
That is, the policy of the university is not to encourage out-of-state students or international students quite as much.
The differential in
Registration fees have been increased.
There is less likelihood of somebody applying on an international basis or from out of state for there to be waivers on any of the admission requirements than there would be in state.
The probation status is tougher.
The deans are more likely to dismiss students that fail to make their probation status than they were.

So there were a number of measures that were not real drastic, but a number of measures taken to slow down the rate of growth a little bit until we could catch up in physical facilities where their needs were.
for faculty and for facilities to support the student body.
Let's talk about your military career.
1942, you went with the 12th Artillery.
Can you tell me about that?
Yes, 12th Field Artillery Battalion was a 155 millimeter
General Support Battalion of the 2nd Infantry Division stationed at Fort Sam Houston, Texas.
I was somewhat familiar with that organization because Battery C of the 12th Field Artillery Battalion was the one that supported our ROTC camp at Camp Willis, Texas in 1938.
The 2nd Infantry Division was one that
distinguished itself in World War I.
It had been stationed at Fort Sam Houston, Texas since World War I.
In fact, the post was really built for an infantry division and the Camp Bullis, something over 20,000 acres, was a maneuver ground and the artillery range for
that division.
Over the years when the military was somewhat de-emphasized, we'd have to say that the 2nd Infantry Division lost quite a bit of its combat readiness.
It was a kind of a parade ground division.
When was this?
Well, I'd say it was a gradual decline in combat readiness from the 20s right up to the mid-30s.
when there was not perceived to be a major international threat.

It was one of the old line divisions around, however, and with the rapid expansion of the Army in the early 40s, three different cadres were taken from the 2nd Infantry Division to start new divisions around.
And the division, of course, as all of the divisions, entered into a much more rigorous training program.
And the honeymoon was over on being a part of the military.
When I first went in, in August of 41, the military had a fairly relaxed training schedule.
Wednesday afternoon and off, no Saturday drill.
But after Pearl Harbor, of course, all that was dropped and training became much more rigorous.
It was obvious that there would be a combat mission for the 2nd Infantry Division.
So they engaged in tougher physical conditioning, military training the first week.
still were firing our artillery on the range at Camp Willis.
How many men were in the division?
About 15,000 men.
The combat division now had been reduced somewhat from the size of the divisions then.
But at full strength it was 15,000?
About 15,000 men at full strength.
And how many people did you have in the battalion, the 12th Artillery, how many men?
Let's see, there were five batteries, a headquarters battery, a service battery, and three firing batteries.
I don't know exactly, but about 600 men.
How many pieces of artillery?
Well in those days, the early days, there were four howitzers per firing battery.
That was later increased to six surgical firing batteries, increased firepower of the artillery battalions.
It was during that time that divisions were being mechanized and the triangular division concept was just being put into effect.
That is- Can you explain that?
Well, yes, the triangular division concept

concept was that there would be three major fighting units infantry regiment with all those four troops with the concept being that the usual commitment normal commitment would be two frontline regiments fighting and one in reserve so that is the way we went into world war ii and each infantry regiment later if they
They got to be called some other things, but the concept was an infantry regiment supported by its artillery, its engineers, its direct support troops, plus then some division troops.
So each regiment had its own, each battle group or regimental group had its own artillery battalion assigned for direct support.
Then there was a medium
artillery, like the 12th Field Artillery, the direct support were 105 millimeter howitzers.
The general support was a 155 millimeter howitzer.
What's the range on these howitzers?
Well, when we, when I first went in the Army, we had the old box trail Snyder, French designed howitzer that wouldn't fire but about 10,000
yards.
But the M-1 hodgers, split trail, came on before World War II and they would fire about 50% increase in range, 15,000-16,000 yards with much more accuracy and much more rapid fire capability.
They were a tremendous improvement over the old box trail Snyder hodgers.
And the 105 Hotcher replaced what previously had been the 75 millimeter Hotcher, which again was a French Hotcher.
And that's the one we trained on, the 75 millimeter, as ROTC cadets.
So the 105 millimeter American manufactured Hotcher just came into the arsenal just before World War II also.
Was it a great improvement?
Oh, it was a tremendous, tremendous improvement.
Not because it had more range, but what are the other reasons?
Well, the principal reason is it had much greater traverse without shifting the trails.
So a gun crew could make a much more rapid response to a fire request.
And it had simplified sights.
The French howitzers were
very complex in their sight adjustments.
They had the French system, which was a plateau and drum.
The ROTC cadets, you had to pick a pretty bright guy on the gun crew to handle the gunner role, because you had to be able to savvy that plateau and drum setting.
So you had to set two different mechanisms on the sites and the advance was just one sighting mechanism, vastly simplified.
And then the centralized fire direction and massing of fire techniques made possible by these new weapons were great factors in World War II.
The Russians
and even the British never really mastered the massing of fire techniques that we had as an artillery tactic.
Why didn't they, if we had this technology?
I don't know, it just wasn't a part of their tactics.
The Germans tended to use more isolated weapons, some direct fire with their 88s, and these were awesome.
But they never had the centralized fire control where they could mass fire a lot of battalions on one target that deserved that much attention.
So the Americans had a big artillery advantage that way.
However, the Germans were, I'd have to say, just as good or maybe better in anti-tank fire and direct fire kind of weapons.
Proximity fuse was another development that really, that was a surprise.
We sprung on them at Christmas time in 1944 because the time fire or air burst were difficult to adjust.
But with the sonar based fuse on a proximity fuse you didn't have to set those at all.
just fire and they'd burst a certain distance above the ground because of the sonar.
That was a big advance.
Though their safety factor wasn't real good.
Occasionally you'd get early bursts on those.
They weren't quite as safe as the previous time fuses.
And radar too.
That's right.
So it burst, maybe they'd burst on trees or maybe in rainstorms or other things that would reflect sound.
Really?
Oh yeah, so they weren't as generally usable and as reliable as a regular time fuse.
They've been perfected since then.
Oh yeah, quite a lot.
Well let's get back to your duties and functions in the 12th Artillery Battalion.
When you started off in April of 1942,
What was your assignment?
I was a reconnaissance officer.
That means, you see there was a battery commander and then an executive officer, a reconnaissance officer and a supply officer.
There were four officers in the battery and the reconnaissance officer's duty was to establish
contact with the supported units, which in our cases frequently were the light artillery battalions.
We'd be assigned to reinforce their fires.
We would establish observation posts, establish a necessary survey, and do fire direction or fire adjustment on observed fire missions.
Well that was Reconnaissance Officer duty.
And how many men did you have under your command?
Oh gosh, it would be a relatively small section in the reconnaissance officer section, probably about 12 or 15.
How about field artillery school where you went after that?
What'd you learn there?
Well that's very ironical.
I didn't go to artillery school until after the war.
I was here October 22nd, 1942 to the 13th of January, 43.
Oh yeah, of course.
Field Artillery School.
Oh that basic, that was a basic officer's course, I did stand corrected on that.
I went to the basic artillery course, artillery officer's course at Fort Selle, Oklahoma and that was a refresher of the same thing I had been given at Texas A&M.
See at that time we had the branches of service in ROTC.
After the war, as ROTC enrollment declined, ROTC became branch general, so they didn't teach the gunnery, the survey, the skills of the artilleryman in ROTC.
They had to get those at service school afterward.
And that's the way it is now.
Early on, you see, we had the different branches.
We had the cavalry, the engineers, the signal, the artillery, the various branches of service we had right in our ROTC on the campus.
We were practically as well prepared as West Point cadet graduates to function in branches of the service.
And we were commissioned in the branches of the service.
When did you get overseas?
Got overseas in September of 43.
Second Division was sent to Northern Ireland.
Northern Ireland?
Northern Ireland.
That's where we went overseas.
Well, of course it's obvious that
The Allies were going to attack Fortress Europe.
The primary attack forces were assembled in England, Great Britain, and the follow-up troops were established as nearby there as they could.
Northern Ireland was nearby, was part of the British Empire, of course.
So that's where we were stationed.
We were there eight months.
Then we got transferred to- In other words, you were just waiting for eight months and training?
We were training hard, yeah, for eight months there.
And of course- What were your feelings when you were there?
Well, we knew what we were there for and
We had real excellent training.
It's ironical that some of our troops were attacked by the Irish Republican Army then.
They were then?
Yeah.
The Irish Republican Army has been a factor over in Ireland ever since Ireland was divided back years and years ago.
And of course they coveted some of our modern weapons and all.
Some of our infantry companies had barely
gotten to their village in Northern Ireland until some little groups attacked them to try to obtain weapons from Irish Republican Army.
And of course, Southern Ireland was off-limits to us, so just the four counties in Northern Ireland where our division was stationed.
In the maneuvers prior to the landing in Normandy,
The three divisions that were identified as assault troops, I think it was the 5th Corps, went on maneuvers.
And two times in a row, one of the divisions, I believe it was the 28th Division, didn't perform well enough.
So they got transferred out of the Corps, and the 2nd Division was moved from Northern Ireland to England.
to Wales, actually, and given a mission of follow-up troops on the invasion.
And that happened just a month before the invasion of Europe.
So we're talking May 1944, then.
That's right.
It's amazing.
The 2nd Division, being an O-line division, had taken winter training.
They were moved from Fort Sam Houston to Camp McCoy, Wisconsin,
in November of 42.
November of 42.
We took cold weather training.
We also took air landing training along the way because aviation was getting to be a factor.
The one kind of training that we had not
been given was amphibious training, waterproofing our vehicles and all that, but that's what we did.
So it really was a crash course in amphibious landings and that sort of thing after we got over to England, Wales.
And prepared yourself then for the invasion.
Prepared for the invasion, you bet.
How did the, first how did the Northern Ireland people respond to your presence and then how did the Welsh?
Well, generally we were fairly well accepted by people in Northern Ireland.
I know in the little town where we were, there was some anxiety about the American soldiers dating the Irish girls.
Really?
that for a while we were under the command of General Patton.
He came over to address us at one time.
I was on duty back at the post.
I really didn't get there to his address, but of course he was a tremendous leader, but kind of a foul mouthed old guy.
He said that
He told the troops assembled there that some of the ladies had complained that the graveyards and all around that there were too many cock sheaths around.
And he said, you know, I told him I'm sure glad our soldiers are using them.
He said, it is my belief that a soldier that won't fight
You know, this is a public speech.
That's what he was saying in the old days.
Of course, we hear that word on television around.
It's not too shocking to hear the word now, but it was a little shocking in those days.
He was a salty old guy.
So if we were taken out from under his command and put under Bradley's command for this 5th Corps for the invasion,
but we later got back under Patton after the St. Louis breakout and we moved down to Brest.
What were the men's feelings toward Patton and Bradley?
Do you remember?
Sure.
Bradley was generally admired and respected, but Patton
was a great leader, but he had a different style.
He was a little more feared, and he was more of a domineering type.
Bradley was considered to be kind of a soldier's general.
He had been an enlisted man himself, and was considered as having far more empathy with troops, whereas Patton was, his style of leadership was different, flamboyant,
domineering driver type.
So I had to say that those were the feelings for those two generals.
I'd say they loved Bradley, but they respected Patton for what he could do, but that they really didn't love him.
Now how had your role changed from being here in Texas to being in Wales?
Okay, along the way I had progressed through the ranks and in Wales I was actually on the ship going to Northern Ireland.
My first command assignment was given to me.
I was designated as communication officer.
